attributes.alt: Cover for The Seesaw by Judith Koppens and Eline van Lindenhuizen. Cover shows a giraffe on one side of a seesaw and a bird on the other.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to practice measurement, engage children with a game, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
Read for enjoyment and understanding, comparing animals by weight.

Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long ”; Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.
Gather classroom objects for children to compare.
Challenge children to compare two objects first by size and then by weight.
How can we make things go?
Is there anything really heavy in the story? What is it?
Can you pretend to play on a seesaw?
Compare different objects. Which weigh more?
Write a story that happens on a playground.
What can you make that weighs a lot?
What is the first letter sound you hear in the word

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to notice and talk about working together and measuring the animals.

Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long ”; Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.
Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Understand a large number of words and begin to use more and more of those words.
Give children materials to work together with a partner to build a seesaw.
Have children place cubes on their seesaws to compare amounts.
How can we make things go?
Do the characters in your book work together? How?
Can you add a friend to your pretend activity?
Weigh objects on a balance scale. Which weighs more?
How can you work together with a friend to move something?
Can you show people working together? What are they doing?
What sounds do you hear in
What can you and a friend build together?

attributes.alt: Cover for The Seesaw by Judith Koppens and Eline van Lindenhuizen. Cover shows a giraffe on one side of a seesaw and a bird on the other.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to review operations, engage children with a song, and introduce vocabulary
How does the seesaw show which side weighs more?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review adding and subtracting one.
Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.

Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long ”; Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.
Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.
Challenge children to weigh objects compared to Connecting Cubes.
Guide children to identify which side weighs more and which side weighs less.
How can we make things go?
What goal does the person in the story have?
Pretend to make muffins. How many did you make? How many is one more? How many is one less?
Count items. How does the count change when you add one more?
What do you and your friends like to play together?
Draw a picture of something tall.
Use letters to make the word
How tall can you make a tower of blocks? Do you think you could make it even taller?

attributes.alt: Cover for The Seesaw by Judith Koppens and Eline van Lindenhuizen. Cover shows a giraffe on one side of a seesaw and a bird on the other.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to discuss operations and counting, engage children with dance, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to counting and working together by showing how many characters pull the yuca.
Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one.

Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long ”; Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Give children Connecting Cubes to represent yuca plants.
Guide children to discuss how adding or taking away one affects the total number in all.
How can we make things go?
Pretend to pull up something big and heavy.
Count how many there are from one side. Then count from the other. Is the number the same?
Write about two people who work together. What happens when one more helps?
Make something that is enormous. How can you tell it is so big?
Which letter sound do you hear at the end of

attributes.alt: Cover for The Seesaw by Judith Koppens and Eline van Lindenhuizen. Cover shows a giraffe on one side of a seesaw and a bird on the other.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to connect the book to physical science, engage children with song, and introduce vocabulary
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
What makes the seesaw go up and down?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and a focus on measurement.

Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long ”; Informally describe and compare the weight of objects using like units and words like “heavy” and “light.
Understand that adding or taking away one from a small group of objects changes the total quantity by one.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the location and movement of common objects.
Support children as they independently respond to the prompt:
How can you meet a goal by working together?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
How can we make things go?
How did characters in the story work together?
What can you do to pretend to make something move?
How many can you count? What happens if you take away one?
Why is it important for people moving something very heavy to work together?
Draw a seesaw. How can you show one side weighs more than the other?
Work with a partner on a tower. What is your goal? How can you work together to make that happen?
